Award.AwardTitle: Dynamics, Ground States, and Elementary Excitations of Quantum Many-Body Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Miniaturization of electronics has been the driving force of the ever increasing power of computers, whether expressed as units of performance per unit of volume, or per unit of energy consumed, or per dollar expended. Miniaturization will reach its ultimate limit when the size of individual components in electronic devices approaches the size of a single atom. Unless we succeed in implementing a new paradigm of computation, called Quantum Computation, the growth in computational efficiency, which is often referred to as Moore's Law, will come to an end. One of the most promising research directions to implement the ideas of Quantum Computation is the development of topological materials. Topological materials have the capacity to store quantum information, which under ordinary conditions is subject to fast deterioration due to a process called decoherence. In this project the PI and his collaborators will study mathematical models of topological materials. The main goal is to better understand the factors that determine the robustness of a quantum memory based on topological materials.

The project will address three questions that are crucial for the possible application of topologically ordered materials to the development of reliable quantum computation devices. First, what determines the rate with which the spectral gap at critical points vanishes as the system size increases? Second, under what conditions is the anyonic excitation spectrum of systems with topologically ordered ground states stable under sufficiently small perturbations? Third, what is the effect of randomness (such as occurs in doped materials) on the structure of the ground state and low-lying excitations of such systems? The project will also investigate the dynamical behavior of the model systems. Questions regarding the energy of low-lying excitations above the ground state, i.e., the spectral gap, are central to many issues in quantum many-body physics. The goal of the project is to significantly extend the range of applicability of methods to estimate the spectral gap in at least two directions. One is the situation where the gap vanishes with increasing system size (critical points or regions). The second aim is to develop methods to analyze the gap of systems in two or more dimensions, which has so far only been achieved in a few special cases. Further, in the case of disordered systems the spectral gap may close, but a so-called mobility gap may play a very similar role and another goal of the project is to extend current methods to situations where the spectral gap is replaced by a mobility gap. Techniques from representation theory, analysis, and probability will be used when available and new methods will be developed when needed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI and his collaborators performed a mathematical study of several classes of model systems with gapped ground state phases and quantum phase transitions that describe the transitions between different ground state phases. These systems model materials that exhibit quantum states of matter, the so-called topological states that underly phenomena such as the fractional quantum Hall effect. A gap in the spectrum of the Hamiltonian above its ground state is an essential ingredient in the physical explanation of the behavior of such materials. In the presence of disorder, the spectral gap may appear in disguise as a mobility gap. The project addressed three important questions. First, what determines the rate with which the spectral gap at critical points vanishes as the system size increases? Second, under what conditions is the anyonic excitation spectrum of systems with topologically ordered ground states stable under sufficiently small global perturbations? Third, what is the effect of randomness (such as occurs in doped materials) on the structure of the ground state and low-lying excitations of interacting many-body systems? Furthermore, the project also investigated the dynamical behavior of the model systems.New results on each of these questions were presented in eleven publications and numerous seminar and conference talks.

Questions regarding the energy of low-lying excitations above the ground state, i.e., the spectral gap, are central to many mathematical problems in quantum many-body physics. The results of the project go beyond proving gap estimates for a few specific models by significantly extending the range of applicability of methods to estimate the spectral gap. In particular, the methods developed in this project extend to the situation where the gap vanishes with increasing system size (critical points or regions). In a second direction, methods were devised to analyze the gap of systems in two or more dimensions, which had until now only achieved in a few special cases. For systems where disorder plays an important role, the project focused on investigating dynamical properties by a direct approach. This led to new results regarding the dynamics of entanglement (the basic resource of quantum information and computation) and introduced the new notion of transmission time to study slow transport in disordered many-body systems.

Mathematical techniques to describe the intricate properties of the quantum states of matter will lead to a better understanding of the physical properties of the materials described by such states. As borne out by previous experiences, this can be expected to lead to better numerical algorithms for the computer simulation of technologically useful materials and devices. Graduate and undergraduate students participated in the project, which provided a rich training environment for students at all levels. Two theses were completed in the course of this project. A series of weekly seminars provided junior collaborators on the project with opportunities to become well-versed in the fundamental theories and gain the ability to bridge the language gap that often hinders the communication between mathematical, physical, and computational scientists working in this area.
